It should be stated that this missive could be interpreted as the incoherent ramblings of a disgruntled ex-employee. I would respond to that by saying that I have worked at many different companies and left jobs for a myriad of reasons. I have never written anything even remotely similar to this about any of my former employers because I have never experienced anything like my time there.
I worked for a company that was purchased by “B&D” in the early 2000s. Within weeks of this acquisition, the writing was clearly written on the veritable wall(s). The following realities became stark early on:
- No relevant decisions are made outside of the boundaries of the HQ located in Towson, MD
- Smaller companies that are absorbed by B&D will quickly find themselves in lockstep with their toxic and inequitable human resource practices and policies
- Black and Decker fosters a self-serving, predatory culture void of anything resembling a work-life balance
- Upper-echelons couldn't care less about the well-being of subordinate employees or their families
- Leadership is unscrupulous, aloof and indifferent toward the workforce in general
- The singular intent of the company is to leverage contrived brand strengths in the hopes of pushing their products upon the unknowing masses
- Their marketing stratagem is a broad-stroke, uninspired and cost-driven approach
- The actual quality of the tangible products is a nonfactor as it relates to their target market(s)
- Their sales force consists mostly of recent college graduates hired on the basis of their physical energy levels and perceived abilities to adhere to market-push methodologies
- Middle management consists almost exclusively of fear-inspired, overworked and largely ineffective “seat-warmers”
- “Burnout” runs rampant throughout the caste system that permeates the entire company
In summary, in a failed national economic state, this company is an iconic manifestation representing the complete avoidance model for potential job-seekers. If you are considering any type of employment there you need to view your prospective tenure as a temporary and painful learning experience. As such, you will learn everything you do not want to be as an employee or a person for that matter. Better companies can most assuredly benefit from your experiences.
advice_to_mgmt: Servant leadership is a leadership philosophy in which the main goal of the leader is to serve. This is different from traditional leadership where the leader's main focus is the thriving of their company or organizations. A Servant Leader shares power, puts the needs of the employees first and helps people develop and perform as highly as possible. Servant leadership inverts the norm, which puts the customer service associates as a main priority. Instead of the people working to serve the leader, the leader exists to serve the people.

review_title: It's Okay but I Know that I Could Do Better.
years_at_company: It's Okay but I Know that I Could Do Better.
pros:
Benefits:
It's nice that they offer an employee contribution for the HSA and HRA. I also like the Stanley Gives 100% match program to whatever charity anyone wants to give to.

Career Growth:
There seems to be a lot of opportunity for everyone in general - there's always jobs available and people get promoted often. I cannot say I see it happen in HR though...

Employee Groups:
SBD has finally hopped onto the diversity and inclusion train with the Women's Network, African Ancestry Network, and hopefully soon a LGBTQ group or even an Asian Network. The company is finally coming up last in the race and now it just needs to finish strong by normalizing these groups.

I can't really think of any more pros because I am honestly burned out... I tried though.
cons:
There is no work-life balance. In the beginning there was and at very short stints between; but I am working nearly as much as I was at my old employer; which was the reason I left there and got paid more money to be nearly as miserable. At this point, I am convinced that Corporate America burns people out as quickly as they can; so I am trying to find a loving start up or untraditional technology organization to work for. At least there I would have the benefits, compensation, and perks. There are no policies about work-life balance in place and I doubt one with breadth will ever generate; it is all verbal which means there is no guarantee.

Managers need training on how to be an inspiring, just, and transformational leader. There are terrible managers in place who have driven their talent away; and the company keeps them because they are scared they won't find anyone else like them. Please! Let them go. Listen to the direct reports; surely all of them are not conspiring against their manager.

Layoffs or not filling roles seem to be everywhere and it is depressing - ask about EXL. It is a terrible work environment waiting on the day one's job will be over with. The morale is gone and I don't think any kind of award or happy hour will bring it back.

In the midst of uncertainty, the communication about the direction of the business is nonexistent. People don't know what is going on but are certain that EXL will eliminate several jobs once projects and initiatives are complete. It is like being on the Titanic (SBD) when the passengers (employees) knew the ship started to fill with water (EXL) but are waiting to see if they want to jump ship (leave SBD) or not (stay until they are terminated).

People are tapped on the shoulder way too much here and they do not even bother to post a role for everyone to have a chance. Even then, a candidate is already identified. It really makes me believe that you can work hard, better yourself professionally and be forgotten; no matter what you do. Nothing makes me believe that I will ever be an executive because of this behind-the-scenes behavior that is rampant at SBD.

This company is SO behind on letting systems make life easier! Mass uploads into every system should be a thing. Accurate data from systems should be a thing. Pulling hundreds of different reports with a few clicks should be a thing. Data integrity should be a thing. I am fed up with this.
advice_to_mgmt:
Remain steadfast and become more aggressive about changing SBD's culture. In terms of large, traditional conglomerates; I do believe we are ahead but definitely not that much - especially when it comes to the affinity groups which many companies have had for years and/or decades! If culture change and diversity really matter, invest in a department to lead this; and not doubling it up into HR or Communications. I believe if we try, we could be as sought after by the best talent in the world as the "cool" tech companies. We really need to be smarter about this because at that point, we would not have to recruit - it would all just flow through the door.

Clip spending elsewhere and throw it into the tuition reimbursement program. This company is too large to just offer the federal maximum. There's a company right down the street from New Britain that pays for everything down to the pencil. How could you let your talent in search of higher learning get away like that? Many millennials and Gen-Xers are buried in student loan debt and/or would love to get their masters. Going "across the street" would be a no brainer to this population; especially since that employer compensates more.

2 weeks of PTO is not enough; especially since we don't have sick or personal time. Everyone needs to start at 3 and work their way up.

Can we please get rid of Wells Fargo for our retirement plan already? How could you stay with them after their irresponsibility last year? A lot of employees are invested in social responsibility which we say we value, so we should have moved on from them if the latter was true.

pros: Work schedules somewhat flexible. Some nice people. Pretty nice culture and professional for the most part, HR being a glaring exception.
cons:
Worked for a brand under Stanley. President lacked foresight or ability to plan and prioritize workload of the team. For
example, when our contracted manufacturer ceased production of our product, there was no plan in place to keep production going at an alternate location even though we were informed of the shutdown months in advance. Result? Layoffs in year 2 of the business. President continually took on new projects that had little or nothing to do with increasing sales. For example, spent a huge amount of our limited budget on a low-exposure PR event that distracted the team from primary job functions and drained already-limited resources. Spent exorbitant amounts of time and money at useless conferences, on phone calls and in meetings that did not further company objectives (i.e. selling) in any way. Lots of activity, few results. Absolutely no real direction in terms of objectives that really mattered in terms of growing the business. Instead a lot of last minute projects that usually failed because President would wait till last minute to communicate them. And those projects usually didn't have any value in the first place. Again, huge amounts of wasted time and money.

President would frequently brush off members of his team on important business and personnel matters. Led to lack of confidence In his leadership and eventually a lack of cohesiveness and trust across the team, with several team members eventually leaving (which President tried to spin as them getting fired, leading to further mistrust). Not to mention, we still had no product to sell. Fortunately it appeared corporate leadership was privy to the fact that there were problems but still were unable - or unwilling - to uproot the problem and find a leader who knew how to prioritize, plan and make money.
advice_to_mgmt: Basic management training for leadership. Hire a confident leader that isn't so easily threatened by legitimate feedback, knows how to grow a business and sets proper priorities so that distractions don't become the norm and staff can focus on productivity.

review_title: Almost 20 years of my life was given to Stanley
years_at_company: Almost 20 years of my life was given to Stanley
pros: I started in1994 as a nail packer in East Greenwich RI. I quickly moved up the ranks and the pay was great, the hours were all I wanted, and I took them all. Working as much as 60-80 hours a week several times throughout my tenure. The mandatory hours were 55 a week. So plenty of work and best pay in RI compared to other companies. I moved up the ranks rather quickly and finally found a great fit for me as a Thread Roll operator/nail polisher. Awesome pay and benefits.
cons: In 99' management decided it was more profitable to send our jobs to Mexico, China, and Poland. This devastated me and my new family, a month prior to closing on the new home I was purchasing. Luckily the TRA saved us from losing everything we had worked so hard for and for so long. Several years later Stanley had realized it wasn't the best move sending the products we made elsewhere. Eventually I got called back and faithfully I went back again as a thread roll operator, but I had to start over again at the bottom of the pay scale. A few years later after reaching the top of my scale they once again decided to close only this time the whole factory was going to Poland, China and Indiana. All this after a 10 million dollar investment in our location to update and expand the facilities to increase our potential growth, reduce costs and improve the overall image of the building itself. The biggest decision by far was the closing of our sister plant in Connecticut that drew the iron wire for our nails and staples. The entire process was moved to our location directly on site and was a huge part of that 10 million dollar fiasco to update and improve our facility and production line. We would no longer have to ship in the wire from CT. It was pulled down to size at our plant now and with that investment in our future we thought we would be set for years to come.... We couldn't have been more wrong.... we bet our lives upon it and lost.
advice_to_mgmt: Focus less on investors and the stock market price, and more on the people who work there, without them you would have no company to grow. Make "Made in the U.S.A." mean something again. Do those things and the stock price will take care of itself and your investors will be happy. Don't allow upper management to overturn decisions made by the previous team based solely on trying to save a buck by cutting your employees throats and making radical changes to make a name for themselves. All to climb the corporate ladder and add a shiny few lines to their resume. At what cost?

review_title: Enormous Company, Low Pay, Unrealistic Expectations
years_at_company: Enormous Company, Low Pay, Unrealistic Expectations
pros:
I was a sales coordinator on the home depot side. The pay is really low for the amount of work that is expected from you. No matter what you do you will only "meet" and never "exceed" expectations. If you do something above and beyond you wont get any sort of recognition or credit for it. The market managers go through a training where they are told to simply find things that you didn't do and rip you apart. Every formal "work with" is just a time for your manager to get the best of you and show you what you are not doing....even though everything you are doing is absolutely perfect.
Relocation is a must in the company. Be prepared to relocate within a month of any sort of promotion. Usually 1000+ miles away.
Your "Market Manager" is not really your manager to impress. The "District Sales Manager" is the only person who can promote you to his or her discretion.
However, the training back in Maryland is phenomenal.
cons: Relocation requirements. Long work days. Working Saturdays during the holiday time and during spring time. Micromanaging you and always wanting to know where you are in your day. Tasks are sometimes unrealistic. Sometimes you have to do a ridiculous task to make your market manager look good without giving you the real credit.
advice_to_mgmt: Give a simple kudos when someone is going far out of their way to make an impression. Don't focus on ripping a new one into someone who hasn't had any direction to do a task they are unaware of. Pay your employees more....lowest pay scale I have ever been a part of.
